translation.en: [Richards] Life's a funny thing, you know.
But I've always thought 30 was about it.
Beyond that would be horrible to be alive.
translation.ko: 그 나이가 지나면 사는 것도 끔찍하다고요

translation.en: Until I got to be 31.
Then, "Why, I ain't so shabby," you know. [laughs]
"I'll hang in a while."
As you go along, you realize that this whole concept of growing up is...
You're not grown up until the day they put you six feet under.
translation.ko: 무덤에 들어가는 그날까지도 사람은 다 자라지 않아요

translation.en: You're never grown up.
♪ I'm blue and lonesome ♪
You don't get bluer than that.
Man, that's bad stuff.
[Richards] The power of the blues was a mind blower.
Anybody who could make a sound like that is all right with me.
translation.ko: 이런 소리를 만드는 사람은 진심으로 존경할 만하죠

translation.en: [chuckles] You know what I mean?
For me, music is like the center of everything.
It's something that binds people together through centuries, through millennium.
translation.ko: 수백 년을 거쳐 사람들을 하나로 묶어주는 매개체죠

translation.en: It's undefinable.
And nobody's ever going to have the answer to it,
but it's great fun exploring.
-Anthony, how are you? -How are you?
-[Richards] Cool, man. -Once again.
Once more into the breach.
[Richards] How you been, Anthony?
-I'm very well, thank you. -Yeah.
So, Keith, I've been enjoying your new music.
translation.ko: 키스, 새로 나온 음악 정말 좋던데요

translation.en: Why don't you tell me a little bit about getting it going?
translation.ko: 새 음악에 대해 말씀 좀 해주시죠

translation.en: You know, what made you decide to jump back in?
I've been thinking about that.
You know, I think it coincided with the fact that I was doing the book, you know...
-Second only to the Bible. -[both chuckle]
And The Stones had one of their...
where they suddenly go into hibernation for about five years.
'Cause we... The Stones had been working a lot until about 2007.
And I was kind of itching to get back in the studio.
I love recording, you see.
Any studio, I feel totally at home there.
Everywhere else, you know, is, you know... there's the bags.
translation.ko: 스튜디오가 아닌 데 있으면 골치가 아프죠

translation.en: [Steve Jordan] Should we get another mic in there?
-Or should we just move the ribbon closer? -[Richards] No, listen...
Play a couple things.
That's better, right?
[Richards] And the next thing I know, Steve Jordan came to me, and he said,
translation.ko: 그러던 어느 날 스티브 조던이 와서

translation.en: "How about just the two of us go in the studio,
you know, just you and me, and we'll cut a couple of tracks?
translation.ko: 트랙 두어 개 녹음해 보자는 거예요

translation.en: Just, you know, see what happens."
[Jordan] He said something and it was kind of shocking.
And I asked him never to say that again.
translation.ko: 제가 다시는 그런 말 하시지 말라고 했죠

translation.en: He said, "Well, you know, I've done all of this... and now the book and everything."
He hadn't been playing.
And he was like, "You know, maybe I should, like, retire," kinda thing.
-Yeah. -At which I completely freaked out.
[laughing] I said, "What are you talking about?"
I was talking in my sleep.
I said, "What are you talking about?"
[man 1] Can you get it? Yeah. [man 2] Yep.
[man 1] Yeah, it's a little boomy. [man 2] Uh-huh.
translation.ko: 네, 저음이 좀 많이 들어간 것 같아요

translation.en: [Tom Waits] Musically, what I noticed about Keith, is he's really big on detail.
And you have to be if you're...
an archeologist and you're, you know... You insist on locality data, you know.
translation.ko: 지역적 데이터를 고수하듯이 음악가도 그럴 수밖에 없죠

translation.en: Not only where something came from,
but what are the principles and the properties of it.
And he... He's like a... like a London cabbie who has The Knowledge.
translation.ko: 온갖 노하우를 다 갖춘 런던 택시 기사 같아요

translation.en: -[man] Yeah, yeah. -Only he has that in music, you know.
[Richards] I realized, as I was doing this stuff,
translation.ko: 작업을 하면서 내가 미국 포크 음악이랑

translation.en: how much steeped I am in American folk music,
in jazz and blues.
That's the stuff that America has given the rest of the world.
translation.ko: 그런 건 미국이 전 세계에 퍼트린 거예요

translation.en: You know, far bigger than H-bombs. [chuckles]
[Richards] Crosseyed Heart, I'm doing a lot of the tipping of the hat to people.
And this was to Robert Johnson.
[Richards] I grew up listening basically to American music,
even though I was in England.
And through that,
I guess I realized that an awful lot of American music, blues included,
relied a lot upon old Celtic melodies,
translation.ko: 고전 켈트 멜로디에 많이 의존한다는 걸 알게 됐죠

translation.en: Irish, Scottish, English, Welsh,
that became part of this country, you know.
So to me, it was translatable easily.
When I first heard Robert Johnson and Lead Belly,
translation.ko: 처음 로버트 존슨과 레드 벨리 음악을 들을 때

translation.en: and I'm hearing an echo...
You know, I'm hearing... In my bones, I'm hearing
translation.ko: 내 뼛속 깊이 울리는 메아리가 들렸어요

translation.en: an echo that I shouldn't be hearing
because it's not within earshot.
Which is one of the reasons I wanted to start this thing off with the blues, you know.
I mean, I ain't a pop star no more, you know.
I don't wanna be. [laughs]
See, I swore... You know, I thought it was in E, for Christ's sake. I mean, I swore...
translation.ko: 난 내가 계속 E로 연주한 줄 알았어

translation.en: I would have gone to the grave saying that I played this in E, man, until today.
translation.ko: 내가 E로 연주한 줄 알고 무덤까지 갈 뻔했네

translation.en: [Richards] My mum was a beautiful music freak with incredible taste.
translation.ko: 어머닌 대단한 음악 취향을 가지고 계셨던 분이에요

translation.en: We only had, like, two radio stations in the whole country, you know.
And she was a wizard of the dial.
If there was anything worth listening to, she would find it.
translation.ko: 들을 만한 게 나오면 바로 찾아냈어요

translation.en: Sarah Vaughan and Ella Fitzgerald were her two top thrushes.
translation.ko: 사라 본, 엘라 피츠제럴드 제일 좋아하셨던 종달새였죠

translation.en: I liked Billie Holiday. Billie had more edge on it for me.
translation.ko: 난 빌리 홀리데이가 취향에 좀 더 맞았어요

translation.en: But still, that's what I grew up with. You know what I mean?
Louis Armstrong...
Billy Eckstine...
and a little dash of Mozart here and there.
And then all the usual rubbish.
translation.ko: 물론 쓰레기 음악도 들을 수밖에 없었죠

translation.en: Whatever they played on radio. You know, the stuff you couldn't avoid, you know.
translation.ko: 라디오에서 나오는 걸 무슨 수로 안 듣겠어요

translation.en: ♪ I'm a pink toothbrush You're a blue toothbrush ♪
translation.ko: 나는 분홍색 칫솔 당신은 파란색 칫솔

translation.en: [Richards] All of that crap, you know? I mean, the '50s, which is, all right, great rubbish, in retrospect.
Growing up in England, just after the war,
there was rubble everywhere.
I was not aware that there was any other world apart from bombed out ruins.
translation.ko: 폭탄으로 폐허가 되지 않은 세상이 있다는 걸 몰랐죠

translation.en: And then, suddenly, Elvis. He hit like a bombshell.
translation.ko: 그때 엘비스가 등장했어요 폭탄 맞은 것 같았죠

translation.en: "Baby Let's Play House" was around then, and it really cooked me.
translation.ko: ‘Baby Let's Play House’ 이 노래에 푹 빠졌어요

translation.en: The world went from black-and-white to Technicolor.
[Richards] America looked very attractive.
All the movies.
We got what you guys saw, like, a year before.
translation.ko: 미국에서 상영하고 1년쯤 후에 볼 수 있었죠

translation.en: Especially if you're into music.
That was basically our lifeline in those days,
that sense of, there's something happening,
and you just wanna be part of it, you know,
translation.ko: 그 일부가 되고 싶어서 발 벗고 뛰어드는 거죠

translation.en: and you jumped in with both feet. At least, I did.
translation.ko: 그 일부가 되고 싶어서 발 벗고 뛰어드는 거죠 적어도 난 그랬어요

translation.en: [Richards] Jim Hall.
[Jordan] We love Jim Hall.
-Jim, motherfucker. -[laughs]
[Richards] My grandfather, Gus, he kinda teased me, man, over years, into becoming a guitarist.
He was one of those guys that always thought
everybody was a musician if they got the chance to be and...
translation.ko: 기회만 닿으면 될 수 있단 생각을 하셨던 분이죠

translation.en: So I think he just left the instruments lying about
just to see if it caught the eye.
translation.ko: 제 눈에 띄길 기다리셨던 것 같아요

translation.en: And then he probably watched me for a couple of years, you know,
talking to him and looking at the guitar and...
translation.ko: 제가 기타를 보고 있으면 이렇게 말씀하셨죠

translation.en: 'Cause I remember him saying, "It's a pretty one, isn't it?
It's nice, that.
Yeah, when you can reach it...
I'll let you play it," you know.
Once he did give me the guitar,
he said the best exercise is the Spanish malaguena,
because it's got a lot of moves in it that make it great for the fingers.
translation.ko: 코드도 많고 손 동작을 익히기 좋다면서요

translation.en: You're expanding yourself without even knowing.
And he was quite right, because, you know, from learning that...
translation.ko: 할아버지 말씀이 맞더라고요 그 곡을 연습하면서...

translation.en: 'Cause I had to learn that in order to get the guitar, you know. I mean...
translation.ko: 기타를 가지려면 그 곡을 연습해야 했거든요

translation.en: That meant I could walk into the house, pick up the guitar and play with it.
translation.ko: 그럼 집에 가서 마음대로 칠 수 있으니까요

translation.en: Until then, it would have to be at invitation only.
-[man] The story with the guitar... -Oh, it's a...
It's a late '50s Gibson ES-355.
translation.ko: “피에르 드 보포트 기타 기술자” 이건 1950년대 후반의 깁슨 ES-355예요

translation.en: So, kind of a hot rod.
He's always been known for playing a black Gibson.
translation.ko: 키스는 블랙 깁슨을 많이 쓰는 걸로 유명하죠

translation.en: For me, it looks like Keith.
And as I just showed you, when I opened the case,
translation.ko: 좀 전에 보여드렸듯이 케이스를 열었을 때

translation.en: he said, "I'll have it." He didn't... Nope. Just... He knew right away.
I've been working with Keith now since the '80s.
I have full access to his guitar lockers and can do what I want.
translation.ko: 기타 보관함에 있는 기타를 마음대로 건드릴 수 있어요

translation.en: I do often get to see guitars and bring them to him.
This is what Robert Johnson would have played, the model and year.
This is a 1928 L-1 Gibson, you know.
And the scale length and the flat neck and the width of the nut...
translation.ko: 눈금 길이랑 플랫 넥이랑 너트 같은 게 유사하죠

translation.en: It was a style of playing.
So you can do the finger style blues on this.
translation.ko: 이걸로 핑거스타일 블루스를 연주할 수 있죠

translation.en: It almost takes you there. It makes you play that way.
translation.ko: 악기가 인도하는 거죠 그런 식으로 연주하게 돼요

translation.en: The notes last the right amount of time.
translation.ko: 딱 적당한 만큼 음이 지속돼서 울려요

translation.en: The balance between the high strings
and what's going on in the low-end, the snap...
In the locker, unfinished project.
National Guitar, right here, in my inventory book of Keith's guitars.
It says here, "To be rebuilt and then maybe used."
And I wrote a note, "Kinda reminds me of Jimmy Reed."
Dig it out, put some strings on it.
And sometimes I pick up an instrument
and the sound will take you to a different place.
translation.ko: 그 소리가 사람을 다른 곳으로 데려다 줘요

translation.en: It's like a flavor.
Steve and Keith walk in. They think we're doing something else.
translation.ko: 스티브랑 키스가 들어와서 뭘 하는지 보더라고요

translation.en: We open the case. Keith looks at it, "Oh, great. Hmm."
"Check this out, Keith.
This has been yours since before I worked for you.
It's never had strings on it.
I found it in the locker, I put strings on it."
Next thing you know, he's out there trying it.
Steve's like, "Okay, if he's in, I'm in."
They start playing, but the control room is set for, you know... for a mix or something.
translation.ko: 둘이 연주를 시작하는데 믹스 장비는 커녕

translation.en: There's no mic set. People aren't ready for this.
"Blues in the Morning," that feeling...
That was just him picking up the guitar.
translation.ko: 키스가 그냥 아무렇게나 한 번 쳐본 거예요

translation.en: There was no second takes, no other tries. It was just where we were going.
translation.ko: 두 번도 아니고 딱 한 번 그걸로 끝이었죠

translation.en: [Richards] To us, in England,
people like Mick and myself and many others...
translation.ko: 믹 재거나 나나 다른 많은 이들은... “머디 워터스 척 베리”

translation.en: Chuck arrived... At the time, we were starving for music.
translation.ko: 척 베리는 우리가 음악에 굶주려 있을 때 나타났어요

translation.en: The way that man hit us...
I'm still recovering.
Incredible lyrics, an incredible devil-may-care attitude.
He's influenced just about every guitar player, even if they don't know it. You know, I mean...
translation.ko: 척 베리의 영향을 안 받은 기타 연주자는 없죠

translation.en: not a lot of guys wanna play like Chuck because it's like taking on the devil.
translation.ko: 척을 따라 하려는 사람은 별로 없어요, 불가능하니까

translation.en: I'll take it on, you know. [laughs]
Yeah, this is the beginning of the Rolling Stones, you know.
Yeah, and I'm holding a full deck here, pals.
That was the one Mick had on the train, you know.
I got on my morning train to go to art school.
translation.ko: 예술 학교에 가려고 아침에 열차를 탔는데

translation.en: I happened to hit the carriage that Mick had just gotten into,
translation.ko: 믹이 타고 있던 칸에 타게 된 거예요

translation.en: and I hadn't seen him in years.
translation.ko: 몇 년 동안 서로 못 보고 지냈을 때죠

translation.en: And then I noticed, tucked under his arm, like this, was...
translation.ko: 봤더니 믹이 팔에 이걸 끼고 있더라고요

translation.en: "Oh, yeah. Get out of here.
Chuck Berry... What you got there, man?"
And then I said, "Come here!"
You know, I thought I was the only other guy in... you know, in the southeast of England
translation.ko: 척 베리를 아는 사람은 잉글랜드 남동부에

translation.en: that even knew anything about this stuff, you know, and...
So, I mean, by the time we got off the train, you know,
we've made a deal, you know. I'm gonna... [chuckles]
And that's how The Stones hooked,
because of these very two records. And that's it.
translation.ko: 바로 이 두 앨범 때문에 탄생된 거죠

translation.en: Muddy, I had only heard, you know, very few tracks of at the time.
translation.ko: 당시 머디의 곡은 별로 못 들어봤을 때라서

translation.en: So this was a mind blower to me, you know.
[Richards] When I first heard The Best of Muddy Waters,
translation.ko: ‘The Best of Muddy Waters’ 처음 들었을 때

translation.en: it was the most powerful music I'd ever heard.
translation.ko: 그때까지 들은 음악 중 제일 강렬하면서도

translation.en: The most expressive.
And I had listened to Mozart and, you know, I had listened to Beethoven.
This is on a par with the best music in the world.
translation.ko: 이건 세계 최고의 음악이랑 동등한 수준이죠

translation.en: The Stones, in their early days,
all we wanted to do was to turn other people on to this.
[Richards] We knew we're never gonna be able to play it like Muddy.
translation.ko: 우리가 머디같이 연주할 수 없다는 건 자명한 일이었죠

translation.en: So let's just, like, juke it up.
translation.ko: 그래서 좀 더 빠르고 경쾌하게 연주했어요

translation.en: We sped it up, we did it real fast. And everybody got into it.
[Richards] We've never wanted to make pop music.
Our puritanical mission was to turn other people on to the blues.
translation.ko: 우리의 청교도적인 미션은 블루스를 전파하는 거였죠

translation.en: At the same time, we realized
that we turned America back on to its own music,
translation.ko: 미국이 원래 미국 음악에 다시 빠져들게 한 거예요

translation.en: which was, like, far beyond the agenda.
translation.ko: 우리가 의도한 것보다 훨씬 거대한 성과였죠

translation.en: The Rolling Stones. Aren't they great?
Unbelievable.
-[Richards] Hey, guys. -What's up, boss?
How are you guys? How're we doing?
-Alright? -Thank you, Keith.
Awesome.
-How you doing? -Great show the other...
-I'm doing fabulous. -Yes, sir. Great show.
-Alright. Yeah, yeah. -Great book, brother.
Cool, brother.
How you doing, Keith?
-We're doing alright, man. -Good.
-Right on. Thank you. -We're all alright, you know.
[Richards] On the road, I feel at home.
Being backstage or being onstage, you know, it's... familiar.
[man] Thank you. [Richards] There you go, pal.
-Okay. -[woman] Can I get a high five? Hi, baby. [laughs]
I left home at 17 in a cloud of disgrace,
without getting, you know, my dad's okay.
And so the road became a second home to me, you know.
[man 1] You brought the sun out. [man 2] Ronnie, how are you?
[Richards] And I'm looking forward still to some great gigs.
I mean, I really enjoyed playing in the heartland.
They're the places we used to drive around in the station wagon 50 years ago.
America is the biggest market in the goddamn world.
It was a fucking crowning glory to break there.
translation.ko: 그런 곳에서 유명해지다니 진짜 뿌듯한 일이었죠

translation.en: [Richards] I was amazed by the warmth of the welcome.
Especially with the first hit being New York City.
[Richards] I mean, the buildings, the feel and the smell of the place.
[Richards] That night, I remember writing to my mum there,
translation.ko: 그날 밤 어머니한테 이렇게 편지를 썼어요

translation.en: "Mum, I'm in New York City.
I'll tell you more later."
[Richards] God knows what they were expecting. In some places, I mean...
translation.ko: 우리한테 뭘 기대하는지 알 수가 없었죠

translation.en: I do remember The Stones being arrested
for topless bathing in Georgia
translation.ko: 조지아 홀리데이 인 호텔이 고속도로 근처에 있었는데

translation.en: at a Holiday Inn swimming pool, which was in sight of this highway.
And some freaked out locals thought, because of the hair,
translation.ko: 우리 머리가 길어서 그런지 동네 주민들이

translation.en: that there was a load of chicks jumping in the pool, naked, you know...
So the cop car drives up to the pool. [laughing]
We're looking at them, the cops are looking at us, you know,
translation.ko: 우린 경찰들을 보고 경찰들은 우릴 보고...

translation.en: and it was like culture shock.
In those days, if you went further south than Washington,
it was a different kind of America then.
It was still strictly segregated.
You'd pull in to a joint, a whole bus of us, black and white, all mixed...
translation.ko: 흑인이랑 백인이 뒤섞여서 버스를 타고 갔는데

translation.en: Anyway, you'd pull over and dying for a pee.
translation.ko: 차에서 내렸을 때 오줌이 너무 마려워서

translation.en: So I'd join in with the brothers,
and then they'd laugh at me and point above the door,
and it said "Colored only."
I asked them, "And where am I supposed to go?" you know.
And they said, "Try the bushes" or, "The white men's around the corner."
translation.ko: 수풀이나 반대편 백인 전용 화장실로 가라고 하더군요

translation.en: But there were plenty of signs of it, yeah. Chain gangs, too. Yeah.
translation.ko: 그런 차별이랑 사슬에 묶인 흑인 죄수들도 많이 보였죠

translation.en: To get the last taste of that bullshit was amazing to behold.
translation.ko: 그런 말도 안 되는 차별을 직접 목격해서 놀라웠어요

translation.en: But I think that black America sort of took us a little more to their hearts
because we were different.
And we had no contact with the problems that they usually had with white people.
translation.ko: 흑인과 백인 사이 일반적인 갈등이 우리 사이엔 없었죠

translation.en: Now that's the shit.
-[Jordan] You're gonna do it? -Only if you want me to.
But there's a Les Paul Jr. behind you.
translation.ko: 레스 폴 주니어가 바로 다음에 나오는데요

translation.en: [Waits] When you walk into his studio...
He says his first home is the stage.
translation.ko: 키스는 자기의 첫 번째 집이 무대라고 말해요

translation.en: I think his second home would be the studio.
translation.ko: 두 번째 집은 아마 스튜디오일 거예요

translation.en: So that's where you have to really start listening.
[Jordan] We're not... We're not using any of this.
translation.ko: 그건... 그건 안 쓰는 게 좋겠어

translation.en: [Waits] Everybody's tuning up and you know, that's when things start to really happen,
translation.ko: 각자 음을 맞추면서 모든 게 시작됩니다

translation.en: uh, because no one thinks it's music yet.
Yeah, it's like an orchestra tuning up, you know. It's thrilling.
translation.ko: 오케스트라가 조율할 때랑 비슷해요, 가슴이 떨리죠

translation.en: Because it's a piece of music they will never play again,
and no one called it that.
Yeah, you don't wanna be looking at the frame and then realize
translation.ko: 어떤 틀을 볼 때 그 틀에서 제일 굉장한 게

translation.en: that the most interesting thing going on in the frame
is happening outside of the frame.
[Richards] Living in England, all you knew about Chicago was Al Capone.
translation.ko: 잉글랜드에선 시카고라 하면 알 카포네밖에 몰랐어요

translation.en: And then I found out that there's something about the stock markets...
and I mean, meat.
translation.ko: 고기나 목축업 같은 것도 있다는 걸

translation.en: [chuckling] I mean, the cattle yards.
The next time I really thought about Chicago
translation.ko: 본격적으로 시카고에 대해 생각하게 된 건

translation.en: is when I heard the blues coming out of this building we're just about to bypass.
translation.ko: 곧 지날 건물에서 나오는 블루스를 들었을 때죠

translation.en: Chess Records, 2120 South Michigan.
We recorded there in '64.
It was a magical room, sound-wise.
How many addresses I've forgotten, that one I'll never forget, you know.
translation.ko: 다른 주소는 다 까먹어도 거긴 절대 못 잊어요

translation.en: We arrived at Chess Studios.
Somebody's walking us through the corridor,
and there's a black guy on a ladder painting the ceiling.
translation.ko: 한 흑인 남자가 천장에 페인트칠을 하고 있었어요

translation.en: As we pass by, the engineer from Chess said,
"Oh, by the way, this is Mr. Muddy Waters."
So this is my first meeting.
I'm shaking hands with Muddy Waters
who's got whitewash dripping.
translation.ko: 그분 얼굴에 흰색 페인트가 뚝뚝 떨어졌어요

translation.en: And he just said...
"Thank you for what you guys are doing."
I had to digest the image later.
I mean, I'm shocked on a personal level
translation.ko: 그 이미지를 나중에 소화해야 했어요 그분 음악을 들으면서 흉내낼 생각도 못 했는데

translation.en: to have met the very man who I've been listening to
translation.ko: 그분 음악을 들으면서 흉내낼 생각도 못 했는데 눈앞에서 직접 보니까 정신이 없더라고요

translation.en: and trying to fathom out.
It said a lot about black and white. [laughs]
But that's what I always said about Muddy.
translation.ko: 머디 얘기가 나오면 전 항상 그 얘길 해요

translation.en: He was a gentleman in no matter what position you found him.
Muddy Waters, Howlin' Wolf, Bo Diddley, Buddy Guy...
translation.ko: 머디 워터스, 하울링 울프 보 디들리, 버디 가이

translation.en: All these guys were out in Chicago recording in the same studios.
translation.ko: 이분들 모두 시카고의 같은 스튜디오에서 녹음했어요

translation.en: And everybody is like, "What do you wanna go to Chicago for?"
Hey, there's a reason.
[Buddy Guy] One, two, three.
How are you doing, Buddy?
-You wanna get a drink? -Yeah.
-You drink corn liquor? -Yeah.
Wait a minute.
-I could have them set you up. -Yeah.
[bartender] All right, white lightning coming at ya.
All right.
It's got a kick, man.
[Guy] Well, you go first. You go first, then I'll...
There we go. I gotta shoot on that one, right?
[Guy] I think I can make this one, Keith.
-[laughs] -Then I scratch.
[Guy] Came here September the 25th, 1957.
They had a thousand blues clubs. Some of them didn't hold but 22 people.
translation.ko: 블루스 클럽 천 개중에 22명이 있는 곳도 있었죠

translation.en: Hardly wasn't no air-conditioning this time of year,
and they kept the doors open
so if you walked by, you would hear these harmonicas and drums.
translation.ko: 행인들한테 하모니카 드럼 소리가 다 들려요

translation.en: And I found out that, if you played good,
translation.ko: 그때 알게 된 게 뭐냐 하면

translation.en: you got a good drunk, and you got a good-looking woman
translation.ko: 연주를 잘하면 술도 공짜 예쁜 여자들도

translation.en: if you sounded all right.
[Guy] Yes, sir.
[Richards] Yep.
I don't know if you remember there was a television show here called Shindig.
And they was trying to get you on...
[Richards] Yeah, Howlin' Wolf was in there.
Yeah, they was trying to get you all to play it. And Mick said...
translation.ko: 그래, 자네들 다같이 출연시키려고 했는데 믹이

translation.en: They said... I think Mick said, "Let us bring Muddy Waters."
translation.ko: 아마 믹이 그랬던 것 같아 ‘머디 워터스도 같이요’

translation.en: And they said, "Who in the hell is Muddy Waters?"
translation.ko: 방송국에서 머디 워터스가 누구냐고 하니까 믹이

translation.en: And he said, "You mean to tell me you don't know who Muddy Waters is?
We named ourselves after one of his famed records, Rollin' Stone."
translation.ko: ‘머디 음반 ‘Rollin' Stone’에서 우리 이름을 딴 건데요’

translation.en: And I even cried about that, man. And sure enough,
translation.ko: 나 그 얘기 듣고 울었잖아 그건 확실해

translation.en: that's when they brought Howlin' Wolf and Muddy.
translation.ko: 그렇게 하울링 울프랑 머디가 빛을 보게 된 거죠

translation.en: And that's the first time I'd ever seen 'em on television.
translation.ko: 그 둘을 TV에서 본 게 그때가 처음이었어요

translation.en: It was thanks to these people here, man.
Tell us something about him, Brian.
Well, when we first started playing together,
translation.ko: 우리가 처음 연주를 시작하게 된 게

translation.en: we started playing because we wanted to play rhythm and blues.
And Howlin' Wolf was one of our greatest idols.
translation.ko: 하울링 울프는 우리한테 우상 같은 존재였죠

translation.en: And it's a great pleasure to find he's been booked on this show tonight.
translation.ko: 오늘 그분과 같이 출연해서 정말 영광입니다

translation.en: -Really is a pleasure. -Thanks to Howlin'.
So I think it's about time that you shut up
-and we had Howlin' Wolf on stage. -[host] Yeah! I agree.
Okay! Let's get him on. Howlin' Wolf! Bring him up.
[Richards] I knew him very well. Chester, I think, was his real name.
translation.ko: 잘 알고 지냈어요 하울링의 본명은 체스터였죠

translation.en: Big man. The gentle giant.
When you're that big and intimidating,
you don't really have to do anything about it.
translation.ko: 아무것도 안 하고 가만 있으면 돼요

translation.en: You know what I mean? [chuckles]
These guys were gentlemen in the true meaning of the word.
I mean, I've no doubt they could be as mean as, you know...
translation.ko: 못되게 굴려면 얼마든지 그럴 수 있었겠지만

translation.en: And I didn't wanna know.
But there was an innate politeness about them.
They were in awe that we'd even heard of them.
translation.ko: 우리가 자신들을 안다는 데 굉장히 놀라워하셨죠

translation.en: And we were in awe of meeting them.
And so you have this mutual appreciation society going on,
which still goes on to this day.
[Guy] Ah! There you go!
I used to go into Chess and try to turn my amplifier up, out loud,
translation.ko: 체스에 가서 앰프 볼륨을 높여놓곤 했어요

translation.en: and they would run me out saying, "Don't nobody wanna hear that."
translation.ko: ‘누가 듣고 싶어 한다고’ 저한테 뭐라고들 했죠

translation.en: But when they started playing and it got back to Leonard, he said,
translation.ko: 그러다 레너드 귀에까지 그 말이 들어갔는데

translation.en: "The British are playing it, and it's getting over."
translation.ko: 영국에서도 그렇게 하니까 반응이 좋다고 하더라고요

translation.en: So I turned my amp up like these British guys.
translation.ko: 그래서 저도 영국인들처럼 앰프 볼륨을 최대한 높였죠

translation.en: Do you have to live that life to be a blues player?
translation.ko: 블루스 연주가가 되려면 그렇게 살아야 하느냐고요?

translation.en: Do you have to be black or white to play the blues?
Hell no, man!
The bottom line, it's about the good and the bad times.
And if you haven't had a bad time in life, just keep living.
translation.ko: 나쁜 경험을 안 해봤다면 계속 그렇게 살아야죠

translation.en: [Richards] All right.
-[Guy laughing] I give up, man. -[Richards laughing]
All right. All right.
Ah, that's where I left it.
Why did I bother to play piano? A guy called Ian Stewart, you know.
He started The Stones,
and he was one of the best boogie pianists I had heard.
translation.ko: 제가 들어본 중 최고의 부기 피아니스트였어요

translation.en: I mean, especially in England.
There was one thing he played.
I said, "Look, I gotta learn how to do that."
Just show me, you know, just the basics.
For me, in the right mood, and at the right instrument,
there's a certain feeling of being an antenna,
receiving and then transmitting.
I'll sit down at the piano and pick up the guitar
and happily play Buddy Holly or Otis Redding.
And then, somewhere, with a bit of luck,
you realize that something you'd thought that you'd played wrong
was actually...
a start of a whole different song.
translation.ko: 완전히 새로운 음악의 시작이라는 걸 깨닫죠

translation.en: I said, "I gotta learn this, man."
I wrote a lot of stuff on piano.
I wrote "Let's Spend The Night Together," "Have You Seen Your Mother, Baby,"
translation.ko: ‘Let's Spend The Night Together’ ‘Have You Seen Your Mother, Baby’

translation.en: but I don't consider myself a piano player.
translation.ko: 하지만 난 내가 피아노 연주가라고 생각하진 않아요

translation.en: I use it as a paint box, you know, just to...
A touch here, a touch there.
Usually just the right hand.
Actually, I piss about a lot. And then it's...
And it's like, whatever strikes me.
But I've always loved playing the piano.
translation.ko: 그래도 피아노 치는 걸 항상 좋아했어요

translation.en: I think one of the reasons...
Being a guitar player, you know, your instrument is in a strange, you know...
a different position.
But the piano, to me, it's, like, laid out like a chess game.
translation.ko: 피아노는 체스 게임처럼 바로 앞에 놓여 있잖아요

translation.en: -See, I love my country shit. -[man chuckles]
See, country music...
I was listening to Porter Wagoner in 1953, man. I mean, yeah,
Johnny Cash, Hank Williams...
We didn't get a lot of it in England,
but, yeah, well aware of it.
My mother made sure of that.
Country music, I mean, to me,
I heard stories that you're never quite sure,
you know, how nasty it can get.
Beautiful woodwork.
The boards, the hallowed boards, yeah.
[Richards] I've only played here once, with Willie Nelson.
translation.ko: 여기서 윌리 넬슨이랑 공연한 적이 있어요

translation.en: It was built as a church.
And now it's a temple to country music.
What's the difference, you know?
We all come here to worship and pray to the best, you know.
translation.ko: 어차피 숭배하고 찬양하러 오는 건 마찬가지잖아요

translation.en: And God knows everybody's been on here.
translation.ko: 여기 안 와본 사람은 없을 거예요

translation.en: I first heard country music on a pirate radio station.
translation.ko: 컨트리음악을 처음 들은 건 해적 라디오 방송이었어요

translation.en: [Marty Robbins singing] ♪ Out in the West Texas town of El Paso ♪ ♪ I fell in love with a Mexican girl ♪
[Richards] Reception was dodgy.
translation.ko: “빌 먼로와 블루그래스 보이스” 수신 상태가 별로 안 좋았죠

translation.en: That required a lot of maneuvering around the room with the antenna, you know? [laughs]
But country music immediately, like, pulled chimes within me, you know.
I mean, it was the melodies, I think, and also the guitars, you know.
You know, that pedal steel's a heartbreaker, man.
Sometimes the songs are really dopey.
But then sometimes the dopiest song would have the best melody.
translation.ko: 하지만 멍청한 노래가 멜로디는 최고일 때도 있죠

translation.en: And at the same time there was a certain edge on certain guys.
Hank Williams, particularly.
You measure country music by this cat.
[Richards] Hank Williams, Johnny Cash, Merle Haggard...
translation.ko: 행크 윌리엄스, 조니 캐시 멀 해거드...

translation.en: They were pretty tough guys.
The reality of country music on the road is something else.
Rock and roll's got nothing on those guys.
The Stones once turned up at a Holiday Inn
in Fresno, something like that.
translation.ko: 홀리데이 인이었나 그런 데 간 적이 있는데

translation.en: And there's this smell of paint everywhere.
They go, "There's your room."
And, "What's going on?" And they said, "Well...
[chuckling] Johnny Cash and Luther Perkins were here two nights ago
translation.ko: 조니 캐시랑 루터 퍼킨스가 이틀 전에 묵었는데

translation.en: and painted the whole damn room orange. Drapes and all," he says.
translation.ko: 방이랑 커튼까지 온통 주황색으로 칠했다는 거예요

translation.en: If I'd have known, I would've brought some paint cleaner.
translation.ko: 미리 알았다면 시너라도 갖고 갔을 거예요

translation.en: [man] You never had any Nudie suits, did you?
[Richards] I'll tell you what,
Gram Parsons used to pass his cast-offs to me, yeah.
translation.ko: 그램 파슨스가 입던 옷을 나한테 주곤 했는데

translation.en: I did have one of Gram's Nudie suits.
translation.ko: 그때 누디 슈트도 하나 얻어 입었어요

translation.en: It was made by a tailor in San Fernando Valley called Nudie.
translation.ko: 샌 페르난도 밸리의 누디라는 재단사가 만든었죠 “누디”

translation.en: We used to go around there, yeah.
What a madman.
Gram Parsons taught me so much about this mystique of the "country."
I was very much drawn to him, and he was the big influence.
translation.ko: 그램한테 굉장히 끌렸고 영향을 많이 받았죠

translation.en: [Richards] Gram hung with us when we were cutting Exile On Main Street and "Wild Horses."
translation.ko: ‘Exile On Main Street’, ‘Wild Horses’ 녹음할 때 자주 어울렸어요

translation.en: Meeting Gram, I got fully immersed in country music.
But as much as he was a country boy and loved his country music,
his idea of America was very bizarre, you know?
translation.ko: 미국에 대한 그램의 생각은 좀 별났어요

translation.en: So, I said, "That's bizarre."
And he said, "You wanna see how bizarre? Look at this."
This guy has got longhorns on the end of his Cadillac.
translation.ko: 누디라는 사람이 자기 차에 뿔을 달아놨더라고요 “누디”

translation.en: So, to me, all of this temple for a Stetson and some rhinestones is like...
But that says the other side of what country music is about.
translation.ko: 어떻게 보면 컨트리음악의 일면을 보여주는 거죠

translation.en: It's the razzle-dazzle.
It's Colonel Parker and the dancing chickens.
Me, I didn't see the Stetson and the rhinestones.
I just heard the music.
And I always knew that this is the heartland.
This is where American music was put in the crucible
translation.ko: 이곳이 바로 미국 음악이 순은으로 다시 태어나는

translation.en: and came out as, you know, pretty much pure silver.
This was rock and roll.
That's where country music and the blues sort of collided.
I always felt myself fortunate to be in a spot where, in America,
translation.ko: 여러 음악이 합쳐지고 또다른 형태로 거듭나는

translation.en: these few forms of music were somehow merging and creating something else, you know?
translation.ko: 미국에 제가 있다는 게 항상 행운으로 느껴졌어요

translation.en: So, it was great to watch and be a part of, and now be the king of.
translation.ko: 그걸 목격하고 일부가 되고 이제 왕의 자리에 올랐죠

translation.en: That was it. Yeah, all right.
Mind you, I don't go around searching for songs, you know, with a butterfly net.
translation.ko: 나비채 들고 노래를 찾아 돌아다니진 않아요

translation.en: Because I think, basically, songs have to come to you.
translation.ko: 노래가 나한테 오는 게 맞다고 생각해요

translation.en: You know, going around, like, trying to winkle them out with a sharp stick,
going, "Come here, you little son-of-a-bitch."
I wrote a sort of country song, roaming around the hallways of this house.
And it's not often, my old lady suddenly came out of the bedroom,
and looked over and said, "That's a good song."
translation.ko: ‘그 노래 괜찮다’하는 건 흔한 일이 아니죠

translation.en: Hey, if the wife says so...
It was very Hank Williams.
And then I thought, "No, it's too Hank Williams.
Let's give it a kick. Let's push it up."
And I loved working with the drummer. It's a one-on-one thing.
And it's an amazingly uncomplicated way to deal with...
Especially playing rock and roll.
And the other thing, too, I mean, just as a fan...
I love the way he plays bass.
[Jordan] That was very exciting for me,
to have Keith play as many instruments as possible.
Because those are some of my favorite Stones records,
translation.ko: 제가 제일 좋아하는 롤링 스톤스 앨범도

translation.en: when he played the bass and all the guitars.
translation.ko: 키스가 각종 베이스랑 기타를 연주한 거 거든요

translation.en: [Richards] I've done some bass tracks in my time. I do love playing bass.
translation.ko: 베이스 트랙 작업도 했어요 베이스 연주도 좋아해요

translation.en: I'm probably a better bass player than I am guitar, actually. [laughs]
translation.ko: 기타보다 베이스 실력이 더 나을지도 몰라요

translation.en: -[man] Look at you! -I love this shit. I love this shit.
Well, that goes back to Steve Jordan saying to me,
"Hey, man," you know, in his sweet, shy, unassuming manner...
translation.ko: 특유의 다정다감하면서도 수줍은 목소리로 묻곤 했죠

translation.en: He went, "How did you cut 'Jumpin' Jack Flash'?"
"How did you cut 'Street Fighting Man'?"
In those days, you know, you'd say, roughly, what time you're, you know,
"What time at the studio?"
You can say 8:00 or 9:00 in the evening, you know, and the band would turn up around midnight. [laughs] You know.
Sometimes I would deliberately go in early, you know, and...
translation.ko: 어떨 땐 일부러 일찍 갈 때도 있어요

translation.en: Or if, you know, I was with Charlie, for instance, I would say, "Let's go in early and..."
translation.ko: 찰리랑 같이 있다든가 하면 일찍 가자고 해서

translation.en: And, basically, I'd go in just to sort of chop a few ideas about.
But now and again, you'd actually find out this is the track.
translation.ko: 그러다 문득 트랙에 들어갈 곡이 나오기도 하죠

translation.en: [Richards on recording] One, two. One, two, three, four.
translation.ko: 하나, 둘 하나, 둘, 셋, 넷

translation.en: "Street Fighting Man," I think, was the first one that occurred that way.
translation.ko: ‘Street Fighting Man’이 처음 그런 식으로 나온 곡이에요

translation.en: Charlie and I were just fiddling about.
And, in there, it sounds like a couple of people busking, you know.
Charlie's playing this tiny, little traveling drum kit,
translation.ko: 찰리는 엄청 조그만 여행용 드럼을 치고

translation.en: and I'm playing an acoustic, you know.
"Yeah, well, let's just build up on it."
There's not an electric guitar on that one, no.
It's all overloaded acoustics.
I realized that I could use a cassette machine basically as a pick-up.
translation.ko: 카세트 기계를 쓸 수 있겠다 싶어서

translation.en: And I play an acoustic guitar through it and, like, slam it through so loud
translation.ko: 거기 대고 엄청 크게 연주를 했더니

translation.en: that it was totally overloaded.
The 1967 Norelco, the same one that you would carry around with you. Found it.
translation.ko: 1967년형 노렐코 카세트 그 당시 거랑 같은 거죠

translation.en: Again. Play.
That's as much as you're gonna get. Let's see what comes out. [chuckles]
Then they'd put a microphone on that and put it into the studio.
Basically, you have an electric guitar, but with the feel of an acoustic.
[Richards on tape] That's as much as you're gonna get.
[Richards] Basically starts there, and Mick would finish it off.
[Richards] We were working so hard in those days that you couldn't write 'em fast enough.
translation.ko: 그 당시 너무 열심히 해서 곡을 다 쓸 수도 없었어요

translation.en: I'll throw the bass on and, you know, put another guitar on,
translation.ko: 베이스도 했다가 또 다른 기타도 했다가

translation.en: and we sort of finished the track in two hours.
translation.ko: 두 시간 만에 트랙을 다 끝냈죠

translation.en: But sometimes, you never know.
You're in a recording, you can go in there with everything sort of planned...
translation.ko: 녹음을 하다 보면 계획을 아무리 잘 해도

translation.en: and it just doesn't click.
[Richards] "Sympathy" was a whole different set-up.
I think that was a good 35 takes.
[man] Sounds really good together.
[Richards] And that song, also, through those takes, went from being a sort of
Dylan-esque sort of ballad, you know, really...
to just an acoustic guitar and a very, sort of... a lament, almost.
translation.ko: 어쿠스틱 기타만 들어가고 애통한 분위기를 자아냈죠

translation.en: And we did that for a bit and went...
"This song could take a little more juice." You know? [laughing]
translation.ko: 뭔가 좀 더 화끈한 게 필요하다는 생각이 들었죠

translation.en: And, slowly, it built up...
Yeah, I took the bass in on that, with Charlie,
and we brought it up to a sort of samba thing.
And then suddenly, everybody looked,
and he said, "Yeah. Yeah, all right, okay."
You never know quite when the magic bit's gonna come in.
translation.ko: 마법의 순간이 언제 일어날지는 알 수가 없어요

translation.en: [Waits] Every song has at least ten songs inside of it
translation.ko: 곡마다 그 안에 10곡이 더 있다고 보시면 돼요

translation.en: that can be released from the song and you can make, you know...
You put two songs together in a room, they'll have offspring, you know?
translation.ko: 두 곡을 한 방에 넣으면 새끼가 생기는 거죠

translation.en: If you want to start writing songs, you have to start thinking like one.
You're trying to break into the ritual of music.
It's kinda like Houdini in reverse, you know.
translation.ko: 후디니의 탈출 마술을 반대로 생각하시면 돼요

translation.en: It's not you're trying to escape. You're trying to be let in.
translation.ko: 탈출하려는 게 아니라 숨어들어 가야 해요

translation.en: [man] The story I'd heard about you meeting him...
translation.ko: 두 분이 만나시게 된 게 ‘Rain Dogs’ 음반

translation.en: I think you were doing Rain Dogs.
translation.ko: “톰 웨이츠 ‘RAIN DOGS’” 작업 하실 때라고 들었는데요

translation.en: Well, my wife, she said, "Who would you like?"
And I told her, "Oh, Keith Richards."
I was, like, saying, "Lenny Bruce..."
"Muddy Waters," you know.
And she went ahead and started calling.
translation.ko: 그랬더니 아내가 전화를 돌려대기 시작한 거예요

translation.en: It was like a prank call.
-And then he picked up, you know. -[man chuckles]
[Richards] We bumped into each other 30 years ago.
I loved him from the minute I met him.
When he came, he came in a semi with about 300 guitars.
So I wasn't ready for that, either, you know.
And he had a guitar valet
who was, like, bringing guitars over like beverages and desserts, you know.
And it was just... It was a little overwhelming for me.
[Richards] Tom's an eccentric. The first time I met him,
he had a room full of instruments of the most bizarre kinds.
translation.ko: 굉장히 특이한 악기를 잔뜩 갖고 있더라고요

translation.en: He had a Mellotron, but it only played train noises. [laughing]
translation.ko: 멜로트론도 그중 하나였는데 기차 소리만 나더군요

translation.en: Yeah, there's a couple of spots.
I just lost the frame, but I don't think it really matters,
translation.ko: 프레임을 놓쳤는데 중요한 건 아닌 것 같아

translation.en: 'cause you can just, you know...
If it gets in the way, you can just drift it off and then put it back up. Yeah, yeah, yeah.
translation.ko: 필요 없을 거 같으니까 밀어낸 다음에 다시 넣든가

translation.en: That first time, we'd been jamming for an hour or so, and then,
translation.ko: 처음 만났을 때 한 시간쯤 같이 연주를 했어요

translation.en: I didn't even... You know... And there were beverages involved.
I must admit, I was trying to match him,
which you must never try to ever do.
translation.ko: 뒤처지지 않는다는 게 말이 안 되는데 말이죠

translation.en: But... And so after an hour or so, I was... I didn't know where I was.
And then, I say, "What did we just get? What, do we have anything?"
translation.ko: ‘지금 연주한 거에서 뭐 좀 나왔나요?’ 했더니

translation.en: And then, he says... [hoarsely] "Scribe."
And then I realized I was the scribe.
I was supposed to be keeping track of everything.
translation.ko: 제가 일일이 기록을 해야 했던 거죠

translation.en: Yeah, something like that.
I'm really happy to have been able to write songs with him, actually.
translation.ko: 같이 곡을 쓸 수 있어서 정말 좋았어요

translation.en: Because it took me a long time to realize that he never wrote songs
translation.ko: 톰은 아내인 캐슬린 말고는 같이 곡을 써본 적이

translation.en: except with Kathleen, his wife, you know.
translation.ko: 없다는 것도 한참 지난 다음에야 알았죠

translation.en: And so, to me, it was a real... I realized, a real privilege.
[Jordan] You know, we could strike that...
[man] You got "Love Overdue." Could you talk about that track?
Hats off, yeah. That was another tip of the hat to...
I've always loved that song and Gregory Isaacs.
I love nearly all of Gregory's work.
There's a certain urgency about it, a truth about it.
And so, we knew we were gonna do it. "Let's do it." You know?
"Give me a reggae beat, Steve." You know?
I've always loved reggae.
Basically, I happened to start living in Jamaica
in '71, '72, just as reggae was catching fire, you know.
translation.ko: 당시 레게 음악이 한창 뜰 때였죠

translation.en: In fact, Catch a Fire had just come out, Bob Marley, and...
translation.ko: “밥 말리와 웨일러스” 밥 말리의 ‘Catch a Fire’ 클리프의 ‘The Harder They Come’

translation.en: Jimmy Cliff, The Harder They Come. There was a whole explosion that year.
translation.ko: “지미 클리프 ‘THE HARDER THEY COME’” 그런 곡들이 그 해에 쏟아져 나왔어요

translation.en: And I'm living there.
[Richards] It felt like the early days of rock and roll.
I felt the same sort of energy and joy
and sense of discovery amongst people,
that they'd found their voice.
[Richards] Jamaica provided an amazing burst of talent and energy.
translation.ko: 자메이카가 이 놀라운 재능과 에너지의 근원이었죠

translation.en: It was very refreshing to me. Yeah, yeah.
And, so, you're sort of back in the beginning of something again.
What I really love about reggae, it's all so...
natural, you know.
There's none of this forced stuff.
And at that time, I was getting really sick of rock music.
translation.ko: 당시 전 록 음악에 신물이 난 상태였죠

translation.en: Rock and roll, I never get sick of.
translation.ko: 로큰롤은 절대 신물이 날 리가 없지만

translation.en: But there was less and less of that and more rock music,
translation.ko: 그건 점점 사라져 가고 록만 두각을 보일 때예요

translation.en: which is actually a white man's version. It turns out to be like...
translation.ko: 로큰롤의 백인 버전이라고 볼 수 있는데...

translation.en: They'll turn it into a march, basically, you know...
♪ We are rockin', yeah! ♪
Yeah, I mean, eventually, that's what... That's their version of rock.
You know, it's like, "Excuse me, I prefer the roll."
And that's when the cats, the Jamaican guys, came in with the horns.
translation.ko: 마침 자메이카 사람들이 나팔을 들고 나타난 거예요

translation.en: Luckily, Steve's very well connected.
[DeCurtis] Yes.
So, I was like, "What we need here is a sort of Jamaican horn section."
translation.ko: 우리 곡에 자메이카 나팔을 넣고 싶었어요

translation.en: Man, we need some more smoke. Get some weed going in this, man.
translation.ko: 연기 좀 피웁시다 대마초 좀 꺼내봐요

translation.en: -Come on, man. -[Richards] I can do that.
-Yeah. -[both laughing]
[Jordan] You got a red, black and green scarf or something?
translation.ko: 빨강, 검정, 초록 스카프라도 있는 거야?

translation.en: Can we get Keith's headband?
No, you're not going to dress me, man. Okay, okay. I will.
translation.ko: 이상한 거 좀 입히지 마 좋아, 맘대로 해

translation.en: [man] So, how did you start recording solo in the first place?
translation.ko: 애초에 어떻게 솔로로 녹음하시게 된 거예요?

translation.en: I was very reluctant to start going solo.
I mean, my thing has always been The Stones and you know...
You'd leave at your peril.
But things had...
Circumstances had worked out in the late '80s, that, you know...
obviously, we were not going to...
Mick and I were not going to be working together for a while.
translation.ko: 믹이랑 같이 작업할 계획은 당분간 없었고요

translation.en: I called 1985 to '89, that was actually World War III.
In a 50-year relationship doing this stuff,
of course, guys have fights, brothers have fights.
translation.ko: 물론 싸움도 많이 했죠 형제들도 싸우니까요

translation.en: You know, we're brothers.
There was no sign of The Stones, like, poking their nose above the horizon.
translation.ko: 롤링 스톤스는 지평선 위로 떠오를 기미가 안 보였어요

translation.en: And I was at, really, a loose end.
Suddenly, I get a call to do the Chuck Berry movie, Hail! Hail! Rock 'n' Roll.
translation.ko: 갑자기 척 베리 영화 출연 제의를 받았어요

translation.en: I mean, obviously, I gotta get into this.
Life wouldn't be complete. I mean, the circle would be unbroken.
translation.ko: 안 하면 미완성 인생으로 끝나게 될 테니까요

translation.en: [Berry] That slur is started right here.
Starts on the upper one.
Listen.
All right.
[man] Was he grateful that you guys were taking the stage?
translation.ko: 출연한 데 대해 감사의 표현을 하던가요?

translation.en: Chuck... Chuck has his own way of showing appreciation.
-Why it was being done? -[Richards] Yeah.
Well, don't touch my amp. Then it won't be done.
translation.ko: 내 앰프 건드리지 마 그럼 안 그러잖아

translation.en: He already said he didn't.
-Well, he says why it's being done. -[man] All right.
Why it's being done is because it's not recording well.
[Berry] Okay.
And that's what's gonna end up on the film.
translation.ko: 영화에 그대로 나가게 될 거 아니에요

translation.en: If it winds up on the film, that's the way Chuck Berry plays it.
translation.ko: 영화에 나가는 게 척 베리 연주가 되는 거야

translation.en: You understand?
-I understand, man. I understand. -Well, I was talking to Andy about it.
But you've got to live with it afterwards. They're trying to--
I've been living for 60 years with it!
-I know that. I know that. -Okay, well, then realize it!
But this is going to be here after we're all dead and gone.
translation.ko: 우리 다 죽고 없어도 이건 영원히 남는 거예요

translation.en: I was in his dressing room...
and the guitar case was open, guitar was lying there.
translation.ko: 기타 케이스가 열려 있고 기타가 놓여 있었어요

translation.en: So, I was waiting for him. They said, you know, "He's coming in a minute."
So, I was just leaning over and I was just touching the strings.
He came in and slammed me. [laughs]
That was Chuck... One of Chuck's greatest hits.
[Richards] No problems could really interfere with the fact that this was just fun.
translation.ko: 즐거움을 주기 때문에 한다는 건 변함이 없었죠

translation.en: [Richards] And that's where I started to work with Steve Jordan.
Steve and I were just like, "We're in rock and roll heaven."
One...
One word from Keith Richards!
Goodnight, ladies and gentlemen.
Tonight's star.
[Richards] Suddenly, I've got this incredible band together.
Hand for the band!
[Richards] And Steve and I find it quite natural to write songs.
translation.ko: 스티브랑 저는 곡 쓰는 재능이 있었어요

translation.en: We said, "Well, let's..." You know, "Here, let's cut some stuff."
Ladies and gentlemen, Keith Richards.
[Waddy Wachtel] When Keith and I first started to play together,
translation.ko: 키스랑 처음 연주하기 시작했을 때 키스가 연주했던 곡과 스트링 치는 것만 듣고도

translation.en: I knew we were simpatico just by hearing what he had done all the years
translation.ko: 키스가 연주했던 곡과 스트링 치는 것만 듣고도

translation.en: and hearing the hands touching those strings.
But, yeah, we bonded pretty extremely, right away.
[Richards] In a way, I thought, "Okay, obviously, I'm supposed to do this,"
translation.ko: 새로운 밴드를 하는 게 운명처럼 느껴졌어요

translation.en: because it was organic.
You'd think one great band in a lifetime is already a miracle.
translation.ko: 하나의 밴드로 성공한 것도 기적 같은 일인데

translation.en: To put two together, I mean, it's weird, in a way.
translation.ko: 두 개를 한다는 게 어떻게 보면 신기하죠

translation.en: I also understood more of Mick's job...
by being the frontman.
translation.ko: 믹의 입장도 이해할 수 있게 됐어요

translation.en: [Richards] To be right on top of everything, from the first note till the end,
translation.ko: 처음부터 끝까지 일일이 신경 써야 한다는 게

translation.en: gave me a bit of discipline, actually, I probably sorely needed.
translation.ko: 저한테 약이 된 것 같아요 꼭 필요한 약이었죠

translation.en: But working outside of The Stones,
translation.ko: 하지만 롤링 스톤스를 떠나 일하다 보니

translation.en: I realized that The Stones, that's my home.
translation.ko: 롤링 스톤스가 집이라는 걸 깨닫게 됐어요

translation.en: We set them up and gave 'em to people, and now we belong to the people.
translation.ko: 밴드를 세상에 내보내니 이제 우리가 세상에 속했죠

translation.en: And I can't let them down.
[reporter 1] The Rolling Stones are back on their first tour in almost a decade.
[reporter 2] This will be their 13th major US tour since 1964.
[reporter 3] The Rolling Stones launched their Bigger Bang world tour last night,
with dates in Canada, the US, South America, Europe, and Asia.
[Richards] About 2007, The Stones had been on the road for a long time.
translation.ko: 2007년 스톤스가 투어에 나선 지 한참 됐을 때

translation.en: And we'd come to a natural gasper, you know, like...
And it occurred to me, maybe this is the time to do a book.
translation.ko: 그래서 책을 쓰면 좋겠다는 생각을 했죠

translation.en: I didn't really take it that seriously to start with.
translation.ko: “‘인생’ 키스 리차드” 처음엔 그다지 진지하게 생각하지 않았어요

translation.en: But as it went on, I understood that...
translation.ko: 하지만 날이 갈수록... “키스 리차드 - ‘인생’ 하나의 인생과 책, 사건”

translation.en: I know who I am and people who know me know basically who I am.
translation.ko: “키스 리차드 - ‘인생’ 하나의 인생과 책, 사건” 내가 누구인지 나도 알고 날 아는 사람들도 알지만

translation.en: But I realize that 999 of them out there still think Keith Richards is
translation.ko: 날 잘 모르는 사람들은 아직도 키스 리차드가

translation.en: smoking a joint, bottle of Jack Daniel's in his hand, like, walking down the road,
translation.ko: 대마초나 피우고 술병 들고 거리를 걷다가

translation.en: you know, cursing the fact that the liquor store is closed.
translation.ko: 술집 문 닫았다고 욕하는 사람으로 안다는 거죠

translation.en: An image, man.
Image like a ball and chain.
It's not like a shadow, because it's there 24/24.
When the sun goes down, it don't disappear.
[Waits] A lot of this has to do with persona.
translation.ko: 사람들 눈에 비치는 모습은 또 다르니까요

translation.en: You have to have some type of armor
so that you can continue to also develop as a human being, you know.
translation.ko: 계속 인간된 모습으로 발전할 수 있죠

translation.en: It's like you have a recipe, and you have a beverage,
and you have a... a sandwich named after you, pretty much.
translation.ko: 내 이름을 딴 샌드위치도 있다 해도

translation.en: It's like, what it comes down to, right?
But you're still able within, inside that... you're able to still grow and change.
translation.ko: 속에서부터 성장하고 변할 수 있는 거죠

translation.en: It's kind of a ventriloquist act a lot of the time, you know.
translation.ko: 복화술사처럼 느껴질 때가 많아요 “마약 없는 미국이 우선!”

translation.en: But it's much safer than putting your own ass out there,
like Judy Garland, you know, and melting every night.
[Richards] You can't buy a persona.
translation.ko: 사람들 눈에 비치는 모습을 살 수는 없어요

translation.en: You can either make it up, or you can be it.
My idea of actual heaven is to be a rock and roll star that nobody ever sees.
translation.ko: 아무도 안 보는 로큰롤 스타가 천국 같아요

translation.en: [laughing] Totally anonymous.
You know, you gotta go out and do this thing sometimes.
translation.ko: 가끔 밖에 나가서 할 일도 하면서요

translation.en: And so after the book came out, the next thing I knew,
Steve came to me and said...
"Let's get away from the chicks." [imitates playing guitar]
And then he's like, "Say we're working, you know what I mean?"
There's fates of rock and roll, you know.
And to do that, you eyeball each other and say...
translation.ko: 그 길을 걸으려면 서로 눈알을 굴리다가

translation.en: "One, two... let's go!"
This is what rock and roll is about.
You feel like you're levitating.
And when all of the guys around you are playing, and you're saying,
"They're feeling it too. I know it, I know it."
translation.ko: 다들 그렇게 느끼는 걸 알 수 있어요

translation.en: And you go for those moments where you actually, you know, fly.
translation.ko: 실제로 나는 듯한 그 순간을 위해 가는 거죠

translation.en: And you just hang on to it as long as you can,
translation.ko: 최대한 오래 그 끈을 놓지 않는 거예요

translation.en: because it is one of the best feelings in the world.
It may be only rock and roll, but...
I'm telling you what...
that's the shit.
♪ Now when I was a young boy ♪
♪ At the age of five ♪
Of all of the people I have ever met, Muddy Waters, he was a father to me.
translation.ko: 지금까지 만난 사람들 중에 머디 워터스는 아버지였어요

translation.en: [man] Yeah, that's right! [Waters] What about Keith?
[Richards] He took me under his wing.
It was just amazing to finally play together.
Was I honored by that? Man, I had died and gone to heaven.
For the first time ever...
A Stones' show, "What are you gonna wear?"
translation.ko: 롤링 스톤스 공연 땐 뭘 입을지 그런 건

translation.en: "We don't give a shit," you know what I mean?
For the Checkerboard show, Ronnie and I were like, "What are we gonna wear, man?"
translation.ko: 체커보드 쇼 때는 로니랑 ‘뭘 입어야 하냐?’

translation.en: "White shirts, black vests." You know? [laughs]
We actually talked about what we were gonna wear before we go on.
translation.ko: 쇼에 나가기 전에 의상 얘기를 한 건 처음이었죠

translation.en: This is the only time, ever, I can remember doing that.
translation.ko: 그때 빼고는 그런 기억이 전혀 없어요

translation.en: Oh, man.
[Richards] Muddy's house.
Wow. You would've thought Chicago could do something more for the man, you know?
translation.ko: 시카고가 이렇게 대접하면 안 되는데 말이죠

translation.en: It was a lot more vibrant the last time I was here.
translation.ko: 마지막으로 여기 왔을 땐 훨씬 활기가 넘쳤어요

translation.en: It was a party. I mean, it was night time.
I think Willie Dixon brought me over.
translation.ko: 윌리 딕슨이 절 데리고 왔던 것 같아요

translation.en: It was rocking when I got here, I remember that.
translation.ko: 도착했을 때 파티가 한창이었던 건 기억나는데

translation.en: It's leaving I don't remember.
I crashed out here. But I woke up in Howlin' Wolf's house.
translation.ko: 여기서 잠든 것 같은데 하울링 울프 집에서 깼죠

translation.en: I don't know what happened. I got carried away.
translation.ko: 어떻게 된 건지 모르겠어요 너무 심하게 즐겼나봐요

translation.en: The party continued, and I went with it.
[Waters] Get Mickey a towel, will ya?
Thank you very much, ladies and gentlemen.
We'll keep the show moving.
Mr. Muddy Waters! Give it to him! Give it to Mr. Muddy Waters.
[man] You know, Muddy was younger then than you are now.
translation.ko: 그때 머디는 지금 키스보다 젊었을 때죠

translation.en: I mean, it seems like you, when you were young,
kind of wanted to be one of those guys.
translation.ko: 그들의 일원이 되고 싶어하셨던 것 같아요

translation.en: And now, in a way, you kind of are one of those guys.
Yeah, I know.
Life's a funny thing, you know.
And nobody wants to get old,
translation.ko: 나이 들고 싶은 사람은 아무도 없겠지만

translation.en: but they don't wanna die young either.
You know, and you just gotta follow this thing down the path, you know.
After I left home, my dad and my mother split up.
And then I lost touch with my dad for 20 years.
Maybe, 'cause I was thinking about, "God, what he must've thought of me?"
translation.ko: 아버지가 어떻게 생각할까 걱정이 됐던 것 같아요

translation.en: I mean, he was a straight-up guy. I mean, a hardworking man and all that.
You know, I mean, the idea of his son being busted for drugs.
I could think of him saying...
"Well, he'd never come to any good."
translation.ko: 아무 짝에도 쓸모가 없다 생각하셨을 것 같았죠

translation.en: After about 20 years, I wrote him a note and got one back.
translation.ko: 20년이 지난 후 편지를 썼는데 답장이 왔어요

translation.en: And we set up a meeting at my house in England.
I took Ronnie Wood with me for protection. That's how scared I was.
translation.ko: 로니 우드랑 같이 갔어요 겁이 났거든요

translation.en: The door opens and out comes out this little old guy.
You know, his legs have gone a bit and he's like...
But it was Dad, you know, and it was...
It was so easy. Within a few minutes, we sorted it all well out.
translation.ko: 너무나 간단했어요 몇 분 안 돼서 다 풀렸죠

translation.en: And he became, for the next 20 years, my best mate.
translation.ko: 그러고 나서 20년 동안 아버진 제 절친이었어요

translation.en: For another 20 years,
he came on every trip, every show, come around the world with me.
translation.ko: 세계 어디로 공연하러 가든 항상 함께 가셨어요

translation.en: And I loved to show him the world.
And he didn't mind seeing it either.
Poor old boy. He's older than I am.
Right, babe?
My family, they're incredibly important, you know.
When you see offspring of offspring, then something else hits home.
translation.ko: 자식의 자식을 보면 또 다른 느낌이 있어요

translation.en: I mean, it's one thing having a kid.
But when you get the grandsons and the granddaughters,
well, that is... that's an amazing feeling.
I don't know of what. Accomplishment? I don't know. Or continuity?
translation.ko: 정확히 뭔진 모르겠어요 성취감? 종족 보존?

translation.en: But basically, love.
[Richards] I've been blessed, man.
I'll play as long as I can get away with it.
translation.ko: 할 수 있는 만큼 연주를 할 거예요

translation.en: And that's all I can do.
translation.ko: 제가 할 수 있는 건 그게 다죠

translation.en: I'm not getting old. I'm evolving.
[man 1] Right on.
-Right on. -[man 2] That was a fine piece of work.
[Richards] Once again, Larry, great to see you, man.
[man 3] All right. [man 4] Oh, yeah. I like this stuff.
[man 5] Yeah, balls to the walls, gentlemen.
